Sub_topics.description: Know that plant and animal cells are eukaryotic and have a cell membrane, cytoplasm and genetic material enclosed in a nucleus. Know that bacterial cells are prokaryotic, much smaller, with cytoplasm and a cell membrane surrounded by a cell wall; genetic material not in a nucleus as a single circular DNA loop and may contain plasmids (small rings of DNA). Be able to demonstrate understanding of scale/size of cells and make order of magnitude calculations including standard form and correct prefixes (centi-, milli-, micro-, nano-).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sub-cellular structures in animal, plant and bacterial cells
Sub_topics.description: Explain how main sub-cellular structures relate to function: nucleus, cytoplasm, cell membrane, mitochondria and ribosomes in most animal cells; plus chloroplasts and a permanent vacuole filled with cell sap in plant cells; plant/algal cell wall of cellulose strengthens cell; plasmids in bacterial cells. Use estimations appropriately to judge relative size/area of sub-cellular structures; recognise/draw/interpret images of cells and organelles (including micrographs).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: light microscope cells drawing (magnification)
Sub_topics.description: Practical knowledge for: using a light microscope to observe, draw and label a selection of plant and animal cells; include a magnification scale. Understand how to calculate magnification from image/real size and how to present labelled scientific biological drawings using correct magnification/scale.

Given information, explain how the structure of specialised cells relates to their function in a tissue/organ/organ system/organism. Required examples: sperm cells, nerve cells and muscle cells (animals); root hair cells, xylem and phloem cells (plants).

Explain the importance of cell differentiation: as organisms develop, cells differentiate to form different cell types; most animal cells differentiate early; many plant cells retain ability to differentiate throughout life. In mature animals, cell division is mainly for repair/replacement. As cells differentiate they acquire different sub-cellular structures and become specialised.

Understand how microscopy techniques have developed; explain that electron microscopy has higher magnification and resolution than light microscopy, enabling study of cells in finer detail and discovery/understanding of more sub-cellular structures. Content limited to differences in magnification and resolution.

Carry out calculations involving magnification, real size and image size using: magnification = size of image / size of real object. Express answers in standard form where appropriate and use correct unit conversions and prefixes (centi-, milli-, micro-, nano-).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Chromosomes, DNA and genes (cell division context)
Sub_topics.description: Know that the nucleus contains chromosomes made of DNA molecules; each chromosome carries many genes. Know that in body cells chromosomes are normally in pairs and use simple models/analogies to explain how cells divide.

Describe the stages of the cell cycle including mitosis (no requirement for named phases of mitosis): cell grows and increases sub-cellular structures (eg ribosomes, mitochondria); DNA replicates to form two copies of each chromosome; in mitosis one set of chromosomes pulled to each end and nucleus divides; then cytoplasm and membranes divide to form two genetically identical cells. Understand importance of mitosis for growth and development of multicellular organisms; recognise and describe contexts where mitosis is occurring.

Define stem cell as undifferentiated cell capable of giving rise to many more of the same type and differentiating into other cell types. Describe function of stem cells in embryos, adult animals (bone marrow) and plant meristems. Know: embryonic stem cells can be cloned and differentiate into most human cell types; adult bone marrow stem cells form many types incl blood cells; meristems can differentiate into any plant cell throughout life. Knowledge of specific stem cell techniques not required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Stem cell therapy, cloning and ethical issues
Sub_topics.description: Understand potential benefits of stem cells for treating conditions (eg diabetes, paralysis). Know therapeutic cloning: embryo produced with same genes as patient; embryonic stem cells not rejected so may be used for treatment. Understand risks (eg viral infection transfer) and that some people have ethical/religious objections. Know plant meristem stem cells used to produce clones quickly/economically; uses include cloning rare species to prevent extinction and cloning crop plants with desirable traits (eg disease resistance). Evaluate risks/benefits and social/ethical issues around stem cells.

Explain diffusion as net movement of particles from higher concentration to lower concentration in solutions or gases; substances move into/out of cells across membranes by diffusion. Required examples: oxygen and carbon dioxide in gas exchange; urea diffuses from cells into blood plasma for excretion by kidneys.

Explain factors affecting diffusion rate: concentration gradient (difference in concentrations), temperature, and surface area of the membrane. Interpret/recognise simple models/diagrams of diffusion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Surface area to volume ratio (SA:V) and exchange
Sub_topics.description: Explain that single-celled organisms have large SA:V enabling sufficient diffusion. Calculate and compare SA:V ratios. Explain need for exchange surfaces and transport systems in multicellular organisms in terms of SA:V. Explain adaptations of exchange surfaces (small intestine, lungs/alveoli in mammals, fish gills, roots and leaves in plants): large surface area, thin membrane/short diffusion path, efficient blood supply (animals), ventilation for gaseous exchange (animals).
Explain osmosis as diffusion of water from a dilute solution to a concentrated solution through a partially permeable membrane; recognise/draw/interpret models/diagrams of osmosis.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: osmosis in plant tissue (mass change)
Sub_topics.description: Practical knowledge for investigating effect of a range of salt/sugar concentrations on mass of plant tissue. Use appropriate measurements and calculations: simple rates of water uptake, percentages, and percentage gain/loss of mass. Plot/draw/interpret appropriate graphs from results.

Explain active transport as movement from more dilute to more concentrated solution against concentration gradient requiring energy from respiration. Examples: absorption of mineral ions into plant root hairs from dilute soil solution; absorption of glucose/sugars from low concentration in gut to higher concentration in blood. Describe and compare diffusion, osmosis and active transport; explain key differences (direction vs gradient, energy requirement, particles involved).

Define levels of organisation: cells are basic building blocks; tissue = group of similar cells with similar structure and function; organ = aggregation of tissues performing specific functions; organ system = group of organs working together; organism formed from interacting organ systems. Understand size/scale relationships across these levels.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Digestive system as an organ system
Sub_topics.description: Describe digestive system as organ system in which several organs work together to digest and absorb food (KS3 assumed). Link enzymes to metabolism (enzymes catalyse metabolic reactions).

Describe enzyme molecules and relate enzyme activity to temperature and pH changes. Explain that enzymes catalyse specific reactions due to shape of active site; use the lock-and-key model as a simplified explanation of enzyme action (and recognise other models may be used). Carry out simple rate calculations for enzyme-controlled reactions.

Recall sites of production and actions of amylase, proteases and lipases. Understand that digestive enzymes convert large insoluble molecules into small soluble molecules absorbed into bloodstream. Know: carbohydrases break carbohydrates to simple sugars; amylase breaks starch; proteases break proteins to amino acids; lipases break lipids (fats) to glycerol and fatty acids. Understand that digestion products are used to build new carbohydrates, lipids and proteins; some glucose used in respiration. Use simple word equations (chemical symbol equations not required).

Know bile is made in liver and stored in gall bladder; bile is alkaline to neutralise hydrochloric acid from stomach. Explain emulsification: bile forms small fat droplets increasing surface area; alkaline conditions and increased surface area increase rate of lipase fat breakdown.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: food tests (Benedict’s, iodine, Biuret)
Sub_topics.description: Practical knowledge for using qualitative reagents to test for carbohydrates, lipids and proteins, including: Benedict’s test for sugars, iodine test for starch, and Biuret reagent for protein. Understand expected observations/colour changes and safe heating where relevant (eg water bath).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: effect of pH on amylase
Sub_topics.description: Practical knowledge for investigating effect of pH on amylase rate using continuous sampling to determine time to completely digest starch at different pH values; use iodine test every 30 s; control temperature with water bath/electric heater. Present results appropriately and calculate rates where required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Heart structure and double circulatory system
Sub_topics.description: Describe structure and function of human heart in a double circulatory system: right ventricle pumps to lungs for gas exchange; left ventricle pumps to rest of body. Blood vessels associated with heart limited to aorta, vena cava, pulmonary artery, pulmonary vein, coronary arteries. Heart valves: names not required. Explain how lungs adapted for gas exchange; lung structures limited to trachea, bronchi, alveoli and surrounding capillary network.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Pacemaker control of resting heart rate
Sub_topics.description: Know natural resting heart rate is controlled by a group of cells in right atrium acting as pacemaker; artificial pacemakers are electrical devices used to correct irregular heart rate.

Describe the three types of blood vessel (arteries, veins, capillaries) and explain how their structures relate to their functions. Use simple compound measures of rate and carry out rate calculations for blood flow where required.

Know blood is a tissue consisting of plasma with red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets suspended. Know the functions of each component. Recognise different blood cells in photographs/diagrams and explain adaptations to function.

Describe coronary heart disease (CHD): fatty material builds up in coronary arteries narrowing them, reducing blood flow and oxygen to heart muscle. Know treatments: stents to keep arteries open; statins to reduce blood cholesterol and slow fatty deposit. Understand faulty valves (do not open fully or leak) and consequences; valves can be replaced with biological or mechanical valves. Know heart failure treatments: donor heart or heart-and-lungs transplant; artificial hearts used as temporary support or to allow recovery. Evaluate advantages/disadvantages of drug, device, and transplant treatments including risks/benefits.

Define health as state of physical and mental well-being. Explain that communicable and non-communicable diseases cause ill health; other factors (diet, stress, life situations) affect physical/mental health. Explain interactions: immune defects increase infections; viruses in cells can trigger cancers; immune reactions can trigger allergies (rashes, asthma); severe physical ill health can lead to depression/mental illness. Interpret disease incidence data (tables/graphs, frequency tables/diagrams, bar charts, histograms, scatter diagrams for correlation) and understand sampling principles in epidemiology.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Non-communicable diseases: human and financial cost
Sub_topics.description: Discuss human and financial cost of non-communicable diseases at individual, local, national and global levels.

Define risk factors as lifestyle aspects or substances in body or environment that increase likelihood of disease. Understand that some risk factors have proven causal mechanisms while others show correlation only.

Explain effects of lifestyle factors on disease incidence. Required examples: diet, smoking and exercise linked to cardiovascular disease; obesity as risk factor for type 2 diabetes; alcohol effects on liver and brain; smoking effects on lung disease and lung cancer; smoking and alcohol effects on unborn babies; carcinogens including ionising radiation as risk factors in cancer. Interpret and evaluate risk factor data including sampling and correlation.

Describe cancer as result of changes in cells leading to uncontrolled growth and division. Distinguish benign tumours (contained, do not invade/spread) from malignant tumours (cancers) that invade neighbouring tissues and spread via blood to form secondary tumours. Know scientists have identified lifestyle risk factors and genetic risk factors for some cancers.

Explain how structures of plant tissues relate to function. Plant tissues include epidermal tissues, palisade mesophyll, spongy mesophyll, xylem and phloem, and meristem tissue at growing tips of shoots and roots. Leaf is a plant organ; knowledge limited to epidermis, palisade/spongy mesophyll, xylem, phloem, and guard cells around stomata. Interpret/produce drawings of transverse leaf sections where needed.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Root hair cells, xylem, phloem: structure and function
Sub_topics.description: Explain adaptations of root hair cells for uptake of water by osmosis and mineral ions by active transport. Describe xylem tissue as hollow tubes strengthened by lignin transporting water and mineral ions from roots to stems/leaves in transpiration stream. Describe phloem tissue transporting dissolved sugars from leaves to rest of plant (translocation); composed of elongated cells with pores in end walls allowing movement of cell sap. Detailed phloem structure/mechanism not required.

Describe transpiration and role of stomata and guard cells in controlling gas exchange and water loss. Explain effects of temperature, humidity, air movement and light intensity on rate of transpiration. Use simple compound measures (rate of transpiration), interpret graphs/tables and translate between graphical and numerical forms for transpiration-related data.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Pathogens and transmission in animals and plants
Sub_topics.description: Explain how diseases caused by viruses, bacteria, protists and fungi are spread in animals and plants. Know pathogens are microorganisms (viruses, bacteria, protists, fungi) that can infect plants/animals and spread by direct contact, water or air. Explain how spread can be reduced/prevented (eg hygiene, isolation, vector control, vaccination where appropriate). Understand bacteria and viruses may reproduce rapidly inside body; bacteria may produce toxins damaging tissues; viruses live and reproduce inside cells causing cell damage.

Know measles is a viral disease with symptoms of fever and red skin rash; can be serious/fatal with complications; most young children vaccinated. Spread by inhalation of droplets from sneezes/coughs.

Know HIV initially causes flu-like illness; unless controlled by antiretroviral drugs it attacks immune cells. AIDS is late stage when immune system badly damaged and cannot deal with other infections/cancers. HIV spread by sexual contact or exchange of body fluids such as blood (eg sharing needles).
Know TMV is a widespread plant pathogen affecting many species including tomatoes; causes distinctive mosaic leaf discoloration reducing photosynthesis and plant growth.

Know salmonella food poisoning spread by bacteria ingested in food or due to unhygienic preparation; in UK poultry vaccinated to control spread. Symptoms include fever, abdominal cramps, vomiting and diarrhoea caused by bacteria and toxins they secrete.

Know gonorrhoea is an STD with symptoms of thick yellow/green discharge and pain on urinating; caused by bacterium; previously easily treated with penicillin until resistant strains appeared. Spread by sexual contact; controlled by antibiotics and barrier contraception (condoms).

Know rose black spot is fungal disease causing purple/black spots, yellowing and early leaf drop; reduces photosynthesis and growth. Spread by water or wind; treated by fungicides and/or removing and destroying affected leaves.
Know malaria is caused by protist pathogen with life cycle including mosquito vector. Symptoms: recurrent fever; can be fatal. Control by preventing mosquito breeding and using nets to avoid bites.

Describe non-specific defences: skin as barrier; nose (eg hairs/mucus) trapping pathogens; trachea and bronchi (mucus and cilia moving mucus); stomach acid. Explain role of immune system if pathogens enter body.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: White blood cells and immune response
Sub_topics.description: Explain how white blood cells defend against pathogens by phagocytosis, antibody production, and antitoxin production. Understand antibodies are specific to pathogens and antitoxins neutralise toxins.

Explain vaccination: introducing small quantities of dead/inactive pathogen to stimulate white blood cells to produce antibodies; on re-infection, rapid antibody production prevents infection. Explain how immunising large proportion of population reduces spread (herd immunity). No need for specific schedules/side effects.

Explain antibiotics (eg penicillin) cure bacterial disease by killing bacteria; specific bacteria should be treated with specific antibiotics. Explain antibiotics cannot kill viral pathogens. Explain painkillers/other medicines treat symptoms but do not kill pathogens; developing antiviral drugs is difficult without damaging body tissues. Understand concerns about antibiotic resistance (linked to resistant bacteria topic).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Drug discovery and development: preclinical/clinical trials
Sub_topics.description: Describe discovery and development of new medicines including: traditional extraction from plants/microorganisms (digitalis from foxgloves; aspirin from willow; penicillin from Penicillium mould discovered by Fleming) and modern synthesis by chemists. Know drugs tested for toxicity, efficacy and dose. Preclinical testing in lab on cells/tissues/live animals. Clinical trials on healthy volunteers and patients: very low doses initially; further trials to find optimum dose; double blind trials include placebo; understand peer review and publication after scrutiny.

Recall photosynthesis word equation: carbon dioxide + water → glucose + oxygen (in presence of light). Recognise symbols CO2, H2O, O2, C6H12O6. Describe photosynthesis as endothermic reaction transferring energy from environment to chloroplasts by light.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Rate of photosynthesis: limiting factors (single factor)
Sub_topics.description: Explain effects of temperature, light intensity, carbon dioxide concentration and amount of chlorophyll on photosynthesis rate. Measure and calculate rates of photosynthesis; extract/interpret graphs involving one limiting factor; plot/draw appropriate graphs with suitable scales; translate between graphical and numerical form; solve simple algebraic rate problems where required.

Explain that limiting factors interact and any one may limit rate. Interpret graphs involving two or three factors and decide limiting factor. Understand and use inverse proportion (inverse square law) for light intensity in photosynthesis context. Apply limiting factors to greenhouse economics (cost effectiveness of adding heat/light/CO2) where data provided.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: light intensity and pondweed photosynthesis
Sub_topics.description: Practical knowledge for investigating effect of light intensity on rate of photosynthesis using aquatic organism (eg pondweed): measure oxygen production rate; control temperature using beaker ‘heat shield’/water bath; safe handling of living pondweed; record results and plot graphs; apply inverse square law at Higher tier when appropriate.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Uses of glucose produced in photosynthesis
Sub_topics.description: Explain that glucose from photosynthesis may be used for respiration; converted to insoluble starch for storage; converted to fats/oils for storage; used to produce cellulose for cell walls; used (with nitrate ions absorbed from soil) to produce amino acids for protein synthesis.

Describe cellular respiration as an exothermic reaction occurring continuously in living cells; energy transferred supplies energy needed for life processes (eg chemical reactions to build molecules, movement, keeping warm). Compare aerobic vs anaerobic respiration in terms of oxygen requirement, products and relative energy transferred.
Recall aerobic respiration word equation: glucose + oxygen → carbon dioxide + water. Recognise symbols C6H12O6, O2, CO2, H2O.
Recall anaerobic respiration in muscles: glucose → lactic acid. Explain incomplete oxidation transfers much less energy than aerobic respiration.

Recall anaerobic respiration in plant and yeast cells: glucose → ethanol + carbon dioxide. Know anaerobic respiration in yeast is fermentation and has economic importance in bread making and alcoholic drinks production.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Response to exercise and oxygen debt
Sub_topics.description: Explain that during exercise heart rate, breathing rate and breath volume increase to supply muscles with more oxygenated blood. If insufficient oxygen, anaerobic respiration occurs, lactic acid builds up and oxygen debt created; fatigue and reduced contraction efficiency during vigorous activity. (HT) Explain lactic acid transported to liver and converted back to glucose; oxygen debt is extra oxygen needed after exercise to react with accumulated lactic acid and remove it.

Define metabolism as sum of all reactions in a cell/body. Explain importance of sugars, amino acids, fatty acids and glycerol in synthesis/breakdown of carbohydrates, proteins and lipids. Know energy transferred by respiration is used for enzyme-controlled metabolic processes. Metabolism includes: conversion of glucose to starch/glycogen/cellulose; formation of lipids from glycerol + 3 fatty acids; use of glucose + nitrate ions to form amino acids and then proteins; respiration; breakdown of excess proteins to form urea for excretion.

Explain homeostasis as regulation of internal conditions of cell/organism to maintain optimum conditions for function in response to internal/external changes; maintains optimum for enzyme action and cell functions. In humans includes control of blood glucose concentration, body temperature and water levels. Control systems may be nervous or chemical. All control systems include receptors (detect stimuli), coordination centres (eg brain, spinal cord, pancreas) and effectors (muscles/glands) producing responses to restore optimum levels.

Explain how nervous system is adapted to enable humans to react and coordinate behaviour: receptors detect stimuli; impulses travel along neurones to CNS (brain and spinal cord); CNS coordinates effectors (muscles contract or glands secrete hormones). Use the sequence: stimulus → receptor → coordinator → effector → response.

Explain structures in reflex arc (sensory neurone, synapse, relay neurone, motor neurone) and relate structures to function; explain why reflex actions are important: automatic and rapid, do not involve conscious part of brain.
Extract and interpret data from graphs/charts/tables about nervous system functioning; translate information about reaction times between numerical and graphical forms.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: factors affecting human reaction time
Sub_topics.description: Practical knowledge for planning and carrying out an investigation into effect of a factor on human reaction time; take time measurements appropriately; present/interpret reaction time data (often using graphs) and consider variables/accuracy.

Describe principles of hormonal coordination and control: endocrine system glands secrete hormones into bloodstream; hormones carried to target organs; effects slower than nervous system but longer lasting. Pituitary gland is ‘master gland’ secreting hormones in response to body conditions and stimulating other glands. Identify positions of pituitary gland, pancreas, thyroid, adrenal glands, ovaries and testes on a diagram.

Explain blood glucose monitored/controlled by pancreas. If blood glucose too high, pancreas produces insulin causing glucose to move from blood into cells; excess glucose converted to glycogen in liver and muscles. Explain how insulin controls blood glucose levels. Interpret graphs showing effect of insulin on blood glucose in people with and without diabetes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Type 1 vs Type 2 diabetes and treatments
Sub_topics.description: Compare Type 1 diabetes (pancreas fails to produce sufficient insulin; treated with insulin injections) and Type 2 diabetes (cells do not respond to insulin; treated with carbohydrate-controlled diet and exercise; obesity is a risk factor). Explain how each can be treated and evaluate information about relationship between obesity and diabetes considering social/ethical issues.

(HT) If blood glucose too low, pancreas produces glucagon causing glycogen to be converted to glucose and released into blood. Explain how glucagon interacts with insulin in a negative feedback cycle to control blood glucose.

Describe roles of reproductive hormones: during puberty, hormones cause secondary sex characteristics; oestrogen produced by ovaries is main female reproductive hormone; eggs begin to mature and ovulation occurs about every 28 days; testosterone produced by testes is main male reproductive hormone and stimulates sperm production.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Menstrual cycle hormones (FSH, LH, oestrogen, progesterone)
Sub_topics.description: Describe roles in menstrual cycle: FSH causes egg maturation; LH stimulates egg release (ovulation); oestrogen and progesterone involved in maintaining uterus lining.
(HT) Explain interactions of FSH, oestrogen, LH and progesterone in control of menstrual cycle; extract and interpret hormone level graphs across cycle.

Evaluate hormonal and non-hormonal contraception methods: oral contraceptives inhibit FSH so no eggs mature; progesterone injection/implant/patch inhibits maturation and release of eggs; barrier methods (condoms, diaphragms) prevent sperm reaching egg; intrauterine devices prevent implantation or release hormone; spermicidal agents kill/disable sperm; abstaining during fertile period; surgical sterilisation. Explain why contraception issues include personal, social, ethical and economic considerations beyond science.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hormones to treat infertility and IVF (HT)
Sub_topics.description: (HT) Explain fertility treatment with hormones: giving FSH and LH to stimulate egg maturation can lead to pregnancy. Describe IVF steps: give FSH and LH to mature several eggs; collect eggs and fertilise with sperm in laboratory; embryos develop; at tiny ball-of-cells stage insert one or two embryos into uterus. Evaluate IVF from patient/doctor perspectives: emotionally/physically stressful; success rates not high; multiple births risk to babies and mother; consider ethical/social issues; link developments in microscopy to IVF.

(HT) Explain roles: adrenaline from adrenal glands in fear/stress increases heart rate and boosts oxygen/glucose delivery for ‘fight or flight’. Thyroxine from thyroid stimulates basal metabolic rate and important in growth/development. Explain thyroxine levels controlled by negative feedback; interpret simple negative feedback diagrams and related data.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sexual vs asexual reproduction and clones
Sub_topics.description: Understand that meiosis produces non-identical cells while mitosis produces identical cells. Sexual reproduction involves fusion of male and female gametes (sperm and egg in animals; pollen and egg in flowering plants), with mixing of genetic information creating variation; gametes formed by meiosis. Asexual reproduction involves one parent, no gamete fusion, no mixing of genetic information, producing genetically identical offspring (clones) via mitosis only.

Explain that cells in reproductive organs divide by meiosis to form gametes: genetic information copied; cell divides twice to produce four gametes each with a single set of chromosomes; gametes genetically different. Explain meiosis halves chromosome number in gametes and fertilisation restores full number; new cell divides by mitosis; embryo develops and cells differentiate. Detailed stages of meiosis not required; use models to explain chromosome behaviour in meiosis.

Describe DNA as polymer of two strands forming a double helix; contained in chromosomes in nucleus. Define gene as small section of DNA on chromosome coding for specific amino acid sequence to make a protein. Define genome as entire genetic material of an organism. Discuss importance of understanding human genome (limited to: searching for genes linked to disease; understanding/treatment of inherited disorders; tracing human migration patterns).

Define and use: gamete, chromosome, gene, allele, dominant, recessive, homozygous, heterozygous, genotype, phenotype. Know some characteristics controlled by single gene (eg mouse fur colour, human red-green colour blindness) and alleles are different forms of a gene. Explain genotype operates at molecular level to produce phenotype. Explain dominant allele expressed if one copy present; recessive expressed only if two copies and no dominant allele. Explain homozygous vs heterozygous for a trait. Recognise most characteristics involve multiple genes interacting (polygenic).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Punnett squares and single-gene inheritance probability
Sub_topics.description: Use probability concepts to predict outcomes of a single-gene cross; use direct proportion/simple ratios for genetic cross outcomes. Complete Punnett squares; extract and interpret information from genetic crosses and family trees.
(HT) Construct genetic crosses using Punnett squares and make predictions using probability; justify predictions from genotype ratios.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Inherited disorders: polydactyly and cystic fibrosis
Sub_topics.description: Explain some disorders are inherited due to inherited alleles. Know polydactyly caused by dominant allele; cystic fibrosis (cell membrane disorder) caused by recessive allele. Make informed judgements about economic, social and ethical issues of embryo screening given information; consider gene therapy as context where relevant (ethical considerations).

Know humans have 23 chromosome pairs; 22 pairs control characteristics and one pair determines sex. Females XX, males XY. Carry out genetic cross to show sex inheritance; use direct proportion/simple ratios.

Describe phenotype development as influenced by genome and environment interaction. Define variation as differences among individuals in a population; variation due to genetic causes, environmental causes, or both combined.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mutations as source of new variants
Sub_topics.description: State that there is usually extensive genetic variation within a population. Recall all variants arise from mutations and that most mutations have no effect on phenotype, some influence phenotype, and very few determine phenotype. Explain mutations occur continuously; rarely a mutation creates new phenotype that may suit environmental change and lead to relatively rapid species change.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evolution by natural selection and speciation
Sub_topics.description: Describe evolution as change in inherited characteristics of a population over time through natural selection, possibly forming new species. Know all life evolved from simple life forms over 3 billion years ago. Explain natural selection: variants with phenotypes best suited to environment survive/reproduce and pass on alleles. Explain speciation: if two populations become so different they cannot interbreed to produce fertile offspring, they are two new species.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Selective breeding (artificial selection) and inbreeding risks
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of selective breeding of food plants and domesticated animals: choose parents with desired traits from mixed population; breed; select offspring with trait; repeat over generations until trait common. Give examples of traits chosen (disease resistance in crops; more meat/milk; gentle dogs; large/unusual flowers). Explain selective breeding can lead to inbreeding and increased susceptibility to disease/inherited defects. Evaluate benefits/risks and related ethical issues.

Describe genetic engineering as modifying an organism’s genome by introducing a gene from another organism to give a desired characteristic. Examples: GM crops resistant to disease, herbicides or insect attack; increased yields; engineered bacteria producing human insulin for diabetes. Explain potential benefits and risks in agriculture and medicine; understand some people object. Concerns include impacts on wild flowers/insects and uncertain long-term effects of eating GM foods.

(HT) Describe main steps: use enzymes to isolate required gene; insert gene into vector (bacterial plasmid or virus); use vector to insert gene into required cells; transfer genes at early development stage so organism develops desired characteristics. Interpret information about techniques and make informed judgements about cloning/genetic engineering issues including GM crops.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evidence for evolution: fossils and antibiotic resistance
Sub_topics.description: Describe evidence supporting evolution including fossils and antibiotic resistance in bacteria. Know evolution theory widely accepted; evidence includes understanding of inheritance in genes, fossil record, and observed evolution of antibiotic resistance. Use data to support theory where provided.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Fossil formation and incomplete fossil record
Sub_topics.description: Define fossils as remains of organisms from millions of years ago found in rocks. Describe fossil formation: parts not decayed due to absent decay conditions; parts replaced by minerals as they decay; preserved traces (footprints, burrows, rootlets). Explain fossil record incomplete due to soft-bodied early life leaving few traces and geological activity destroying evidence; thus uncertainty about how life began. Extract/interpret information from charts/graphs/tables including evolutionary trees.

Define extinction as no remaining individuals of a species alive. Describe factors that may contribute to extinction (eg environmental change, new predators, disease, competition, human impacts) given context.

Explain why bacteria evolve rapidly: fast reproduction; mutations produce new strains; some resistant strains survive antibiotic treatment and reproduce so resistant population increases and spreads; people not immune and no effective treatment. Know MRSA is resistant. Explain how to reduce development rate: avoid inappropriate prescriptions (eg for non-serious or viral infections); patients complete antibiotic course; restrict agricultural antibiotic use. Understand development of new antibiotics is costly/slow and may not keep up with resistance emergence.

Describe traditional classification by Linnaeus: kingdom, phylum, class, order, family, genus, species; organisms named by binomial system (genus and species). Use information to show understanding of Linnaean system.

Describe impact of developments in biology on classification: improved microscopes and biochemical understanding led to new models; chemical analysis evidence supports three-domain system by Woese: Archaea, Bacteria, Eukaryota (includes protists, fungi, plants, animals). Explain evolutionary trees as models showing relationships using current classification data and fossil data; interpret evolutionary trees.

Describe levels of organisation in an ecosystem from individual organism to the whole ecosystem. Define ecosystem as interaction of community (biotic) with non-living (abiotic) environment. Define stable community as one where population sizes are fairly constant.

Explain importance of interdependence and competition in communities. Plants compete for light, space, water and mineral ions; animals compete for food, mates and territory. Species depend on others for food, shelter, pollination and seed dispersal; removing one species can affect the whole community. Given information, suggest what organisms compete for and how they are adapted.

Explain how changes in abiotic factors affect communities given data/context. Abiotic factors: light intensity, temperature, moisture, soil pH and mineral content, wind intensity/direction, CO2 levels for plants, oxygen levels for aquatic animals. Interpret abiotic factor data from charts/graphs/tables.

Explain how changes in biotic factors affect communities given data/context. Biotic factors: availability of food; new predators; new pathogens; one species outcompeting another so numbers insufficient to breed. Interpret biotic factor data from charts/graphs/tables.

Explain how organisms are adapted (structural, behavioural, functional) to survive in their natural environment given information. Define extremophiles as organisms living in very extreme environments (high temperature, pressure or salt concentration), eg bacteria at deep-sea vents.

Understand photosynthetic organisms are producers of biomass. Represent feeding relationships as food chains beginning with producers synthesising molecules (green plants/algae making glucose by photosynthesis). Define primary, secondary, tertiary consumers. Define predators and prey; understand predator-prey population cycles in stable communities and interpret graphs modelling these cycles.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sampling in ecology: transects and quadrats (and required practical)
Sub_topics.description: Know ecologists use transects and quadrats to determine distribution and abundance of species. Required practical knowledge: measure population size of common species in habitat; use sampling techniques to investigate effect of a factor on distribution. Apply sampling principles; calculate arithmetic means; use mean/mode/median; plot appropriate graphs with suitable scales; make population estimates from samples.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cycling of materials: carbon cycle and water cycle
Sub_topics.description: Recall that materials cycle through abiotic and biotic ecosystem components. Explain importance of carbon and water cycles to living organisms: carbon returned to atmosphere as CO2 via respiration and decomposition for photosynthesis; water cycle provides fresh water via evaporation and precipitation and drainage to seas. Interpret/explain diagrams of carbon and water cycles. Nitrogen cycle not required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Decomposers and microorganisms in nutrient cycling
Sub_topics.description: Explain role of microorganisms (decomposers) in cycling materials: return carbon to atmosphere as CO2 and mineral ions to soil; link to decomposition processes in ecosystems.

Define biodiversity as variety of different species on Earth or within an ecosystem. Explain how biodiversity ensures stability by reducing dependence of one species on another and maintaining physical environment; explain human reliance on biodiversity and that human activities reduce biodiversity; explain impacts of waste, deforestation and global warming on biodiversity.

Explain that human population growth and higher living standards increase resource use and waste; improper handling causes pollution. Pollution types: water (sewage, fertiliser, toxic chemicals), air (smoke, acidic gases), land (landfill, toxic chemicals). Explain pollution reduces biodiversity by killing plants/animals.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Land use, peat bogs and carbon dioxide
Sub_topics.description: Explain how building, quarrying, farming and dumping waste reduce land available to other organisms. Explain that destroying peat bogs to produce compost reduces habitat biodiversity; decay/burning of peat releases CO2. Understand trade-offs/conflict between cheap compost/food production and conserving peatlands to protect biodiversity and reduce CO2 emissions.

Describe causes of large-scale tropical deforestation: land for cattle/rice fields and growing crops for biofuels. Evaluate environmental implications of deforestation (including biodiversity loss and CO2 effects).

Know CO2 and methane levels increasing and contribute to global warming. Describe some biological consequences of global warming (eg habitat change, distribution shifts, extinction risk) given context; understand scientific consensus based on peer reviewed evidence and that evidence may be uncertain/incomplete in complex contexts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Maintaining biodiversity: conservation actions and evaluation
Sub_topics.description: Describe positive and negative human interactions in ecosystems and impact on biodiversity. Describe conservation programmes: breeding programmes for endangered species; protection/regeneration of rare habitats; reintroduction of field margins/hedgerows; reduction of deforestation and CO2 emissions by governments; recycling resources rather than landfill. Evaluate methods to tackle human impacts and explain conflicting pressures on maintaining biodiversity using given information.

Topics.Topic_name: Atomic structure and the periodic table

Sub_topics.description: Know all substances are made of atoms; an atom is the smallest part of an element that can exist. Know elements are represented by chemical symbols (eg O, Na) and about 100 elements exist; elements shown in periodic table.

Explain compounds are formed from elements by chemical reactions; reactions form new substances and often involve detectable energy change. Know compounds contain two or more elements chemically combined in fixed proportions; represented by formulae; can only be separated into elements by chemical reactions.

Represent reactions by word equations and by balanced symbol equations using formulae. Use names and symbols of first 20 elements, Group 1 and 7 elements, and others in spec; name compounds from given formulae or equations; write word equations; write formulae and balanced equations for reactions in spec. (HT) Write balanced half equations and ionic equations where appropriate.

Define mixture as two or more elements/compounds not chemically combined; chemical properties of components unchanged. Describe and explain separation by physical processes: filtration, crystallisation, simple distillation, fractional distillation, chromatography; no chemical reaction and no new substances made. Suggest suitable separation/purification techniques for mixtures from given information; understand safe use of apparatus for separation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early atomic models: spheres to plum pudding
Sub_topics.description: Explain that new experimental evidence can change or replace scientific models. Describe progression from indivisible spheres to discovery of electron to plum pudding model (positive sphere with embedded electrons).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Alpha scattering and the nuclear model
Sub_topics.description: Describe alpha particle scattering experiment leading to nuclear model (mass concentrated at centre, charged nucleus) replacing plum pudding model. Explain why scattering evidence led to model change; distinguish plum pudding vs nuclear model.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Bohr model and discovery of neutrons
Sub_topics.description: Describe Bohr model where electrons orbit at specific distances and energy levels. Know proton identified as unit positive charge in nucleus. Know Chadwick provided evidence for neutrons in nucleus approximately 20 years later. Details of Bohr calculations and Chadwick experimental method not required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Subatomic particle charges and neutral atoms
Sub_topics.description: Know relative charges: proton +1, neutron 0, electron −1. Know in an atom number of electrons equals number of protons; atom has no overall charge. Atomic number = number of protons; atoms of same element have same proton number; different elements have different proton numbers. Use nuclear model to describe atoms.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Size, mass and isotopes; nuclear notation
Sub_topics.description: Know atom radius about 0.1 nm (1×10−10 m); nucleus radius about 1×10−14 m (<1/10 000 atom radius). Almost all mass in nucleus. Know relative masses: proton 1, neutron 1, electron very small. Mass number = protons + neutrons. Define isotopes as atoms of same element with different neutron numbers. Represent atoms using nuclear notation (mass number over atomic number). Calculate numbers of protons, neutrons and electrons in atoms/ions from atomic number and mass number. Relate atomic/nuclear scale to physical world objects; use SI units and nano prefix; use standard form as needed.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Relative atomic mass from isotopic abundances
Sub_topics.description: Define relative atomic mass (Ar) as average value accounting for abundance of isotopes. Calculate relative atomic mass from percentage abundances of isotopes.

Describe electrons occupying lowest available energy levels (shells). Represent electronic structure as numbers (eg Na 2,8,1) and as diagrams. Be able to represent electronic structures of first 20 elements in both forms; accept energy levels/shells terminology.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Periodic table arrangement and electron structure links
Sub_topics.description: Explain periodic table arranged by increasing atomic (proton) number; columns are groups with similar properties occurring periodically. Explain elements in same group have same number of outer shell electrons giving similar chemical properties. Explain position relates to electron arrangement and atomic number; predict possible reactions and reactivity from periodic table position.

Describe early classification by atomic weight; early tables incomplete and some elements incorrectly placed when strict weight order used. Explain how Mendeleev left gaps for undiscovered elements and sometimes changed order based on properties. Explain that predicted elements were discovered and filled gaps; isotopes later explained why atomic weight order not always correct. Understand how testing predictions supports/refutes scientific ideas.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Metals vs non-metals (properties and periodic table position)
Sub_topics.description: Define metals as elements reacting to form positive ions; non-metals do not form positive ions. Know metals mostly on left/bottom; non-metals on right/top. Explain differences between metals and non-metals using characteristic physical and chemical properties; relate atomic structure to periodic table position; link reactions to electron arrangement and atomic number.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Group 0 noble gases: electron structure and trends
Sub_topics.description: Know Group 0 are noble gases; unreactive and do not easily form molecules due to stable outer electron arrangements (8 outer electrons except He with 2). Explain boiling points increase down group with increasing relative atomic mass. Predict properties from trends down group; relate to outer shell electrons.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Group 1 alkali metals: reactions and reactivity trend
Sub_topics.description: Know Group 1 alkali metals have one outer electron giving characteristic properties. Describe reactions of first three alkali metals with oxygen, chlorine and water. Explain that reactivity increases down the group; predict properties from trends; relate to outer electrons.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Group 7 halogens: properties, compounds and displacement
Sub_topics.description: Know Group 7 halogens have seven outer electrons; similar reactions; non-metals existing as diatomic molecules. Describe compounds formed when chlorine, bromine and iodine react with metals and non-metals. Know down Group 7: relative molecular mass, melting point and boiling point increase; reactivity decreases. Explain displacement reactions: more reactive halogen displaces less reactive halogen from aqueous solution of its salt. Predict properties from trends; relate to outer electrons.

Topics.Topic_name: Bonding, structure, and the properties of matter

Sub_topics.description: Know three types of strong chemical bond: ionic (oppositely charged ions), covalent (atoms share pairs of electrons), metallic (atoms share delocalised electrons). Know ionic bonding in compounds of metals with non-metals; covalent bonding in most non-metal elements and compounds of non-metals; metallic bonding in metallic elements and alloys. Explain bonding in terms of electrostatic forces and transfer/sharing of electrons.

Explain ionic bonding via electron transfer: metals lose electrons to form positive ions; non-metals gain electrons to form negative ions; ions from Groups 1 and 2 metals and Groups 6 and 7 non-metals achieve noble gas electronic structure. Draw dot-and-cross diagrams for ionic compounds formed by metals in Groups 1 and 2 with non-metals in Groups 6 and 7. Determine ion charge from group number for these groups.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Giant ionic lattices and empirical formula from models
Sub_topics.description: Know ionic compounds form giant structures (lattices) held by strong electrostatic attractions in all directions. Recognise representations of sodium chloride lattice (dot-cross, ball-and-stick, 2D/3D diagrams) and deduce ionic nature from structure diagrams. Describe limitations of these representations for giant ionic structures. Determine empirical formula of ionic compound from model/diagram showing ions and their ratios. Structures of ionic compounds other than NaCl not required.

Explain covalent bonds formed by sharing pairs of electrons; bonds are strong. Recognise substances consisting of small molecules from formula; recognise polymers as very large molecules; recognise giant covalent structures (diamond, silicon dioxide).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Representing covalent bonds: dot-cross and structural diagrams
Sub_topics.description: Represent covalent bonds with dot-and-cross diagrams and with lines for single bonds. Draw dot-and-cross diagrams for molecules: H2, Cl2, O2, N2, HCl, H2O, NH3, CH4. Represent repeating unit of polymers using bracket notation with n. Describe limitations of dot-cross, ball-and-stick and 2D/3D diagrams. Deduce molecular formula from given model or diagram showing atoms and bonds.

Know metals are giant structures of atoms in regular pattern; outer electrons delocalised and free to move through structure; sharing delocalised electrons creates strong metallic bonds. Recognise metallic giant structure diagrams and relate to properties (conductivity, malleability).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: States of matter and the particle model
Sub_topics.description: Know three states: solid, liquid, gas; melting and freezing at melting point; boiling and condensing at boiling point. Use simple particle model to explain changes of state. Predict state at different temperatures from data.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Forces between particles and state changes
Sub_topics.description: Explain that energy needed for state changes depends on strength of forces between particles; stronger forces mean higher melting and boiling points. Relate particle type to bonding and structure; explain change-of-state temperatures in terms of energy transfers and bonding. Recognise atoms do not have bulk properties.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Limitations of the simple particle model (HT)
Sub_topics.description: (HT) Explain limitations of the simple particle model: does not account for forces between particles, represents all particles as solid spheres, and treats spheres as solid and inelastic.
Use state symbols (s), (l), (g), and (aq) in chemical equations; include appropriate state symbols for reactions in this specification.

Explain ionic compounds have high melting/boiling points due to strong attractions in giant ionic lattices requiring lots of energy to break. Explain conduction: when molten or dissolved in water, ions free to move so conduct electricity; when solid, ions fixed so do not conduct.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Properties of small covalent molecules and intermolecular forces
Sub_topics.description: Explain that small-molecule covalent substances are usually gases/liquids with low melting/boiling points due to weak intermolecular forces between molecules; melting/boiling overcomes intermolecular forces not covalent bonds. Explain that intermolecular forces increase with molecular size so larger molecules have higher melting/boiling points. Explain why small molecular substances do not conduct electricity (no overall charge). Use comparison of intermolecular forces vs covalent bonds to explain bulk properties.

Know polymers have very large molecules with atoms linked by strong covalent bonds; intermolecular forces between polymer molecules are relatively strong so polymers are solids at room temperature. Recognise polymer structures from bonding diagrams.

Know giant covalent structures are solids with very high melting points because many strong covalent bonds must be broken to melt/boil. Recognise giant covalent structures from diagrams. Examples: diamond, graphite, silicon dioxide.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Metals and alloys: structure and hardness
Sub_topics.description: Explain metals have high melting/boiling points due to strong metallic bonding. Explain malleability of pure metals due to layers of atoms sliding. Explain alloys harder than pure metals because different-sized atoms distort layers and prevent sliding.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Metals as electrical and thermal conductors
Sub_topics.description: Explain metals conduct electricity because delocalised electrons carry charge through metal. Explain metals conduct thermal energy because energy transferred by delocalised electrons.

Explain diamond: each carbon forms four covalent bonds in giant covalent structure; therefore very hard, very high melting point, does not conduct electricity. Link properties to structure and bonding.

Explain graphite: each carbon forms three covalent bonds in hexagonal layers with no covalent bonds between layers; layers can slide. One electron per carbon delocalised enabling electrical conductivity. Link properties to structure and bonding; note graphite similar to metals due to delocalised electrons.

Know graphene is a single layer of graphite with useful properties for electronics/composites; explain properties from structure/bonding. Define fullerenes as carbon molecules with hollow shapes based on hexagonal rings and may include 5- or 7-membered rings; Buckminsterfullerene C60 spherical. Know carbon nanotubes are cylindrical fullerenes with high length:diameter ratios; uses in nanotechnology, electronics, materials. Recognise graphene/fullerenes from diagrams/descriptions; give examples of fullerene uses including nanotubes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Conservation of mass and balancing equations
Sub_topics.description: State law of conservation of mass: no atoms lost/made in chemical reactions so mass of products equals mass of reactants. Explain balanced symbol equations represent conservation of atoms; understand multipliers (coefficients) and subscripts in formulae; balance equations by adjusting coefficients not subscripts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Relative formula mass (Mr) and percentage composition
Sub_topics.description: Calculate relative formula mass (Mr) as sum of relative atomic masses in formula. Understand that in balanced equations, total Mr of reactants in given quantities equals total Mr of products in given quantities. Calculate percentage by mass of an element in a compound using Mr and Ar values.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mass changes in reactions involving gases
Sub_topics.description: Explain apparent mass changes in open systems due to gases as reactants/products not being accounted for (eg metal + oxygen increases mass; thermal decomposition of metal carbonates releases CO2 leaving metal oxide). Given balanced equation, explain mass change using particle model and identify gas escaping/entering; relate to experimental setups.
Explain that all measurements have uncertainty. Represent distribution of results and estimate uncertainty; use range about the mean as a measure of uncertainty.

(HT) Define mole (mol) as unit for amount of substance; mass of 1 mole in grams equals relative formula mass. Know one mole contains Avogadro constant NA = 6.02 × 10^23 particles per mol. Apply mole concept to atoms, molecules, ions, electrons and equations (eg 1 mol C atoms equals number of molecules in 1 mol CO2). Use significant figures and standard form appropriately.
(HT) Use relative formula mass to calculate number of moles from given mass and vice versa: n = m/Mr and m = n×Mr (symbol rearrangement).

(HT) Interpret balanced symbol equations in terms of moles (stoichiometric ratios) and calculate masses of reactants/products from equation and mass of a given reactant/product; substitute values with correct units.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Balancing equations from masses via moles (HT)
Sub_topics.description: (HT) Calculate balancing numbers (coefficients) from masses of reactants/products by converting grams to moles, finding simple whole-number ratios and writing balanced equation; change subject of equations where needed.

(HT) Explain limiting reactant as reactant completely used up limiting amount of product; explain effect of limiting quantities on product yield using moles or masses in grams and stoichiometric ratios.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Concentration in g/dm³ and related calculations
Sub_topics.description: Define concentration of solution as mass of solute per volume of solution (g/dm^3). Calculate mass of solute in a given volume for known concentration. (HT) Explain relationship between mass of solute, volume of solution and concentration (c = m/V and rearrangements). Use ratios, fractions, percentages and equation rearrangement as needed.
Know metals react with oxygen to produce metal oxides; these are oxidation reactions because metals gain oxygen. Explain oxidation and reduction in terms of gain/loss of oxygen.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reactivity series from reactions with water and acids
Sub_topics.description: Explain that metal reactivity relates to tendency to form positive ions. Recall and describe reactions (if any) of potassium, sodium, lithium, calcium, magnesium, zinc, iron and copper with water or dilute acids at room temperature (no steam reactions) and use these to place metals in reactivity series; include hydrogen and carbon in series conceptually. Explain relation between reactivity and tendency to form positive ion; deduce order of reactivity from experimental results; explain displacement: more reactive metal displaces less reactive metal from a compound.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Extraction of metals by reduction with carbon
Sub_topics.description: Know unreactive metals (eg gold) may be found native; most metals in ores as compounds. Explain metals less reactive than carbon can be extracted from oxides by reduction with carbon; reduction is loss of oxygen. Content limited to reduction of metal oxides using carbon; detailed extraction process steps not required. Interpret/evaluate extraction processes from given information and identify substances oxidised/reduced by oxygen gain/loss.

(HT) Define oxidation as loss of electrons and reduction as gain of electrons. Write ionic equations for displacement reactions; identify oxidised and reduced species in given reactions/symbol equations/half equations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Acids reacting with metals to make salts and hydrogen
Sub_topics.description: Know acids react with some metals to produce salts and hydrogen gas. Reaction knowledge limited to magnesium, zinc and iron with hydrochloric and sulfuric acids. (HT) Explain these as redox reactions in terms of electron loss/gain and identify oxidised/reduced species in equations.

Know acids neutralised by alkalis (soluble hydroxides) and bases (insoluble hydroxides/oxides) to produce salts and water; acids react with carbonates to produce salts, water and carbon dioxide. Predict products from given reactants. Determine salt identity from acid (HCl→chlorides, HNO3→nitrates, H2SO4→sulfates) and positive ions from base/alkali/carbonate. Use formulae of common ions to deduce salt formulae.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Making soluble salts and crystallisation (required practical)
Sub_topics.description: Describe making soluble salts by reacting acids with insoluble solids (metals, oxides, hydroxides, carbonates): add excess solid until no more reacts; filter off excess; crystallise salt from solution; produce pure, dry sample. Required practical knowledge: prepare pure, dry soluble salt from insoluble oxide/carbonate using Bunsen burner to heat dilute acid and water bath/electric heater to evaporate; safe techniques for filtration, evaporation and crystallisation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: pH scale and neutralisation (H+ and OH−)
Sub_topics.description: Know acids produce hydrogen ions H+ in aqueous solutions; alkalis produce hydroxide ions OH−. Use pH scale (0–14) as measure of acidity/alkalinity; measure with universal indicator or pH probe. Know pH 7 neutral; acids pH<7; alkalis pH>7. Neutralisation reaction: H+(aq) + OH−(aq) → H2O(l). Describe use of indicator to estimate pH; use pH to identify acidic/alkaline solutions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Strong vs weak acids and pH scale (HT)
Sub_topics.description: (HT) Define strong acid as completely ionised; examples: hydrochloric, nitric, sulfuric. Define weak acid as partially ionised; examples: ethanoic, citric, carbonic. For given concentration, stronger acid has lower pH. Understand that pH decrease by 1 corresponds to 10× increase in [H+]. Use and explain dilute vs concentrated (amount of substance) and weak vs strong (degree of ionisation). Describe neutrality and relative acidity in terms of [H+] and pH (whole numbers).

Explain that ionic compounds melted or dissolved in water have ions free to move, so conduct electricity and are electrolytes. Describe electrolysis: passing current through electrolyte causes ions to move to electrodes; cations to cathode (negative), anions to anode (positive); ions discharged to form elements. (HT) Write half equations for electrode reactions and complete/balance supplied half equations where required across electrolysis content.
Predict products of electrolysis of binary ionic compounds in molten state using inert electrodes: metal at cathode, non-metal at anode (eg PbBr2 gives Pb at cathode, Br2 at anode).

Explain why electrolysis is used to extract metals too reactive for carbon reduction or that react with carbon; high energy costs for melting and electricity. Describe aluminium extraction by electrolysis of molten aluminium oxide in cryolite using carbon anode: explain why mixture used (lower melting point/increased conductivity) and why positive electrode must be replaced (carbon reacts with oxygen products).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Electrolysis of aqueous solutions: predicting products
Sub_topics.description: Predict products of electrolysis of aqueous solutions with inert electrodes based on relative reactivity: at cathode, hydrogen produced if metal more reactive than hydrogen; at anode, oxygen produced unless halide ions present then halogen produced. Explain because water provides H+ and OH− which may be discharged. Predict products for aqueous solutions containing a single ionic compound.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: electrolysis of aqueous solutions
Sub_topics.description: Practical knowledge for investigating electrolysis of aqueous solutions using inert electrodes, including developing a hypothesis, setting up electrochemical cell, observing products at electrodes and recording observations safely.

(HT) Explain that at cathode cations gain electrons (reduction) and at anode anions lose electrons (oxidation). Represent electrode reactions with half equations; examples: 2H+ + 2e− → H2 and 4OH− → O2 + 2H2O + 4e− (or 4OH− − 4e− → O2 + 2H2O).

Define exothermic reactions as those that transfer energy to surroundings causing temperature increase. Examples: combustion, many oxidation reactions, neutralisation. Uses include self-heating cans and hand warmers. Explain energy conservation: products have less energy than reactants by the amount transferred.

Define endothermic reactions as those that take in energy from surroundings causing temperature decrease. Examples: thermal decomposition, citric acid and sodium hydrogencarbonate reaction. Uses include cold packs. Distinguish exothermic and endothermic by temperature change.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: temperature changes in reacting solutions
Sub_topics.description: Practical knowledge for investigating variables affecting temperature changes in reacting solutions (eg acid + metals, acid + carbonates, neutralisations, displacement reactions). Plan method, measure temperature changes accurately, record data, calculate means/graph relationships and evaluate method improvements and uncertainties as required.

Explain that reactions occur when particles collide with sufficient energy; activation energy is minimum energy needed. Draw and interpret simple reaction profiles (energy level diagrams) for exothermic and endothermic reactions showing relative energies of reactants/products, activation energy, overall energy change; identify reaction type from profile; explain meaning of activation energy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Bond energies and calculating energy change (HT)
Sub_topics.description: (HT) Explain energy must be supplied to break bonds and is released when bonds form; use bond energies to calculate energy changes. Overall energy change = total energy to break bonds in reactants − total energy released forming bonds in products. Explain exothermic when energy released > energy required; endothermic when energy required > energy released. Calculate energy transferred using supplied bond energies.

Topics.Topic_name: The rate and extent of chemical change

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Rate of reaction calculations and graphs
Sub_topics.description: Calculate mean rate of reaction as quantity of reactant used or product formed divided by time: mean rate = quantity used/time or quantity formed/time; quantity measured by mass (g) or volume (cm^3); rate units g/s or cm^3/s; (HT) also use moles and mol/s. Draw and interpret graphs of quantity vs time; draw tangents and use slope as measure of rate; (HT) calculate gradient of tangent for rate at specific time.

Recall factors affecting reaction rate: concentration of reactants in solution, pressure of reacting gases, surface area of solid reactants, temperature, and presence of catalysts. Describe effect of changing each factor on rate (increase/decrease).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: concentration and rate (gas volume & colour/turbidity)
Sub_topics.description: Practical knowledge for investigating how concentration affects reaction rate using (1) measuring volume of gas produced and (2) change in colour or turbidity; develop hypothesis; plan/control variables; record time/volume/endpoint; calculate rates; plot graphs; evaluate uncertainties and improvements.

Use collision theory to explain rate changes: reactions occur when particles collide with sufficient energy (activation energy). Increasing concentration/pressure/surface area increases collision frequency; increasing temperature increases collision frequency and collision energy. Predict/explain effects of concentration, pressure and temperature; explain surface area effects via surface area to volume ratio; use simple proportionality reasoning.

Define catalysts as substances that change reaction rate without being used up; different reactions require different catalysts; enzymes are biological catalysts. Explain catalysts increase rate by providing alternative pathway with lower activation energy; draw catalysed vs uncatalysed reaction profiles showing lower activation energy with catalyst. Identify catalysts from being unchanged and not in overall equation; explain in terms of activation energy.

Explain reversible reactions: products can react to form original reactants; represented by ⇌ between reactants and products (eg A + B ⇌ C + D). Describe that direction can change by changing conditions (given examples such as ammonium chloride ⇌ ammonia + hydrogen chloride with heat/cool).

Explain that if reversible reaction is exothermic in one direction, it is endothermic in the reverse direction with same energy transfer magnitude; apply to examples given (eg hydrated/anhydrous copper sulfate; hydrated/anhydrous cobalt chloride).
Explain that in closed system preventing escape, equilibrium reached when forward and reverse reactions occur at exactly same rate.
(HT) Predict qualitatively how equilibrium position changes with changing conditions; system responds to counteract imposed change (Le Chatelier’s Principle).

(HT) Explain that changing concentration of reactant/product disturbs equilibrium; system shifts until equilibrium re-established. Increasing reactant concentration shifts to make more products; decreasing product concentration shifts to make more products. Interpret given data to predict equilibrium changes.

(HT) Predict temperature effects: increasing temperature favours endothermic direction (more products for endothermic forward), decreases products for exothermic forward; decreasing temperature favours exothermic direction. Interpret given data to predict changes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Effect of pressure on gaseous equilibrium (HT)
Sub_topics.description: (HT) For gaseous equilibria: increasing pressure shifts equilibrium toward side with fewer gas molecules; decreasing pressure shifts toward side with more gas molecules. Use balanced symbol equation to count molecules; interpret data to predict effects.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Crude oil as finite resource; hydrocarbons and alkanes
Sub_topics.description: Know crude oil is finite resource found in rocks; formed from ancient biomass mainly plankton buried in mud. Know crude oil is mixture of many compounds; most are hydrocarbons (H and C only). Know most hydrocarbons in crude oil are alkanes with general formula CnH2n+2. Know first four alkanes: methane, ethane, propane, butane. Recognise alkanes from formulae/structural representations (displayed, molecular).

Explain fractional distillation separates crude oil into fractions with similar carbon chain length by evaporation and condensation (boiling point differences). Know fractions processed to produce fuels and petrochemical feedstock. Recall major fuels from crude oil: petrol, diesel, kerosene, heavy fuel oil, liquefied petroleum gases. Know petrochemical industry produces solvents, lubricants, polymers, detergents. Names of other specific fractions not required.

Recall properties depending on molecule size: boiling point, viscosity, flammability; describe trends with increasing molecular size (bp↑, viscosity↑, flammability↓). Explain these properties influence fuel use. Write balanced equations for complete combustion of hydrocarbons with given formula producing CO2 and H2O; recognise combustion releases energy and involves oxidation of C and H.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cracking, alkenes and bromine water test
Sub_topics.description: Explain cracking breaks long-chain hydrocarbons into smaller more useful molecules; describe conditions for catalytic cracking and steam cracking in general terms. Know cracking produces alkanes and alkenes; alkenes more reactive than alkanes. Recall bromine water test: bromine water decolourises (orange to colourless) with an alkene. Balance cracking equations from given reactant/product formulae. Explain uses: high demand for small-molecule fuels; alkenes used to make polymers and other chemicals; explain how modern life depends on hydrocarbons.

Define pure substance in chemistry as single element or compound not mixed with any other substance. Know pure substances have fixed melting and boiling points; melting/boiling point data used to distinguish pure substances from mixtures/impure substances. Understand everyday ‘pure’ may mean unadulterated (eg pure milk). Use mp/bp data to distinguish pure vs impure.

Define formulation as designed mixture with specific purpose; components mixed in carefully measured quantities to achieve desired properties. Identify formulations from information. Examples include fuels, cleaning agents, paints, medicines, alloys, fertilisers, foods; component names of proprietary products not required.

Explain chromatography using stationary and mobile phases; separation depends on distribution between phases. Explain paper chromatography separates mixtures; use chromatograms to distinguish pure vs impure substances (pure gives single spot in all solvents). Calculate and interpret Rf value: Rf = distance moved by substance (centre of spot from origin) / distance moved by solvent. Understand different compounds have different Rf values in different solvents; use Rf to help identify substances; report appropriate significant figures.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: paper chromatography of coloured substances
Sub_topics.description: Practical knowledge for separating and identifying coloured substances using paper chromatography; measure distances and calculate Rf values; compare chromatograms for different substances/mixtures and interpret results.
Describe test for hydrogen: burning splint at mouth of test tube; hydrogen burns with a ‘squeaky pop’.
Describe test for oxygen: glowing splint relights when inserted into oxygen.
Describe test for carbon dioxide: bubble/shake gas through limewater (aqueous calcium hydroxide); limewater turns milky/cloudy.
Describe test for chlorine: damp litmus paper bleached/turns white in chlorine gas.

Recall approximate composition for last 200 million years: about 80% nitrogen, about 20% oxygen, small proportions of other gases including carbon dioxide, water vapour and noble gases. Use ratios/fractions/percentages where required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Earth’s early atmosphere and volcanic origins
Sub_topics.description: Describe theory: first billion years had intense volcanic activity releasing gases forming early atmosphere and water vapour condensing to oceans. Early atmosphere may have resembled Mars/Venus today: mainly carbon dioxide with little/no oxygen; volcanoes also produced nitrogen which built up; small proportions methane and ammonia. Explain that evidence is limited over 4.6 billion years and that theories develop; interpret evidence and evaluate different theories given information (no other theories required).

Explain oxygen produced by algae and plants via photosynthesis: 6CO2 + 6H2O → C6H12O6 + 6O2. Algae first produced oxygen about 2.7 billion years ago; oxygen then appeared in atmosphere; plants evolved and oxygen increased over next billion years enabling animals to evolve.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Decrease of carbon dioxide and formation of carbon stores
Sub_topics.description: Explain carbon dioxide decreased due to photosynthesis and formation of sedimentary rocks and fossil fuels containing carbon. Describe/explain formation of limestone, coal, crude oil and natural gas as carbon stores. Describe main atmospheric changes over time and likely causes.

Know greenhouse gases (water vapour, carbon dioxide, methane) maintain Earth temperatures to support life. Describe greenhouse effect in terms of interaction of short-wavelength (incoming) and long-wavelength (infrared, outgoing) radiation with matter and atmosphere.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Human activities increasing CO2 and methane; evaluating evidence
Sub_topics.description: Recall two human activities that increase CO2 (eg burning fossil fuels, deforestation) and two that increase methane (eg cattle/rice paddies, landfill). Understand that many scientists believe human activity increases average temperature and causes climate change but modelling is complex leading to uncertainty; evaluate quality of evidence in reports, describe uncertainties, recognise role of peer review and communicating results to audiences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Effects and risks of global climate change
Sub_topics.description: Describe briefly four potential effects of global climate change (eg sea level rise, changing rainfall patterns, habitat changes, extreme weather). Discuss scale, risk and environmental implications.

Define carbon footprint as total CO2 and other greenhouse gas emissions over full life cycle of product/service/event. Describe actions to reduce CO2 and methane emissions (eg energy efficiency, renewables, reduced travel, improved farming practices) and give reasons actions may be limited (economic, practical, political).

Explain combustion of fuels major source of pollutants. Know fuels contain carbon/hydrogen and may contain sulfur. Describe how burning fuels produces CO2 and water vapour; incomplete combustion produces carbon monoxide and soot/particulates; sulfur produces sulfur dioxide; high temperatures in engines produce oxides of nitrogen; unburned hydrocarbons and particulates may be released. Predict combustion products given fuel composition and conditions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Properties and effects of atmospheric pollutants
Sub_topics.description: Explain carbon monoxide is toxic, colourless/odourless. Explain sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides cause respiratory problems and acid rain. Explain particulates cause global dimming and health problems. Describe and explain problems caused by increased pollutant levels.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Finite vs renewable resources and sustainable development
Sub_topics.description: Explain humans use Earth’s resources for warmth, shelter, food, transport; natural resources plus agriculture provide food/timber/clothing/fuels; finite resources from Earth/oceans/atmosphere processed for energy/materials. Define sustainable development as meeting needs of current generations without compromising future generations. Give examples of natural products supplemented/replaced by agricultural and synthetic products. Distinguish finite vs renewable resources from given information. Extract/interpret resource information from charts/graphs/tables and use orders of magnitude to evaluate significance of data.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Potable water and water treatment methods
Sub_topics.description: Explain potable water has low dissolved salts and microbes; potable is not chemically pure.
