Describe UK potable water production from fresh water: choose source, filter through beds, sterilise (chlorine, ozone or UV). Explain desalination needed when fresh water limited; describe distillation and reverse osmosis (membrane) and that these require large amounts of energy. Distinguish potable vs pure water; describe differences in treating ground water vs salty/sea water; explain reasons for treatment steps.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: water analysis and purification
Sub_topics.description: Practical knowledge for analysing and purifying water samples from different sources, including measurement of pH, dissolved solids, and purification by distillation. Evaluate methods and sampling where relevant; interpret results.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Waste water treatment and resource difficulty comparison
Sub_topics.description: Describe waste water treatment needs for sewage/agricultural and industrial waste water. Sewage treatment stages: screening and grit removal; sedimentation producing sludge and effluent; anaerobic digestion of sludge; aerobic biological treatment of effluent. Comment on relative ease of obtaining potable water from waste, ground and salt water.

(HT) Explain limited metal ores and low-grade copper extraction alternatives: phytomining (plants absorb metal compounds; harvest and burn to ash containing metal compounds) and bioleaching (bacteria produce leachate containing metal compounds). Explain metal obtained from solutions by displacement using scrap iron or by electrolysis. Evaluate alternative biological methods given information, including environmental impacts vs traditional mining.

Describe LCA stages: extracting/processing raw materials; manufacturing/packaging; use/operation; disposal/end of life, including transport/distribution at each stage. Explain quantifying energy/water/resources/wastes can be straightforward but assigning numerical values to pollution effects requires value judgements; LCA not purely objective. Explain selective/abbreviated LCAs can be misused to reach predetermined conclusions. Carry out simple comparative LCAs (eg plastic vs paper shopping bags) given data and interpret LCAs.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reduce, reuse, recycle: materials and trade-offs
Sub_topics.description: Explain reducing use, reusing and recycling reduces use of limited resources, energy, waste and environmental impacts. Know metals, glass, building materials, clay ceramics and most plastics made from limited raw materials; energy often from finite resources; quarrying/mining impacts environment. Explain reuse of glass bottles; recycling glass by crushing/melting; recycling metals by melting/recasting or reforming; separation depends on material and desired properties; eg scrap steel added to blast furnace iron to reduce ore extraction. Evaluate ways to reduce use of limited resources given information.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Energy stores, systems and energy accounting
Sub_topics.description: Define system as object or group of objects; describe changes in energy stores when a system changes. For common situations, describe energy store changes before/after (eg object projected upwards; moving object hitting obstacle; object accelerated by constant force; vehicle slowing down; heating water in kettle). Calculate energy changes when system changed by heating, mechanical work by forces, and electrical work by current flow. Use calculations to show on a common scale how total energy in system is redistributed (conserved) when system changes; apply energy conservation and correct units (J).
Calculate kinetic energy using Ek = 1/2 m v^2. Know units: Ek in joules (J), m in kilograms (kg), v in metres per second (m/s). Rearrange and substitute values with correct units.

Calculate elastic potential energy in stretched spring using Ee = 1/2 k e^2 (assuming limit of proportionality not exceeded). Units: Ee in J, spring constant k in N/m, extension e in m. Apply and rearrange equation appropriately.
Calculate gravitational potential energy gained when object raised: Ep = m g h. Units: Ep in J, m in kg, g in N/kg (value given), h in m. Apply and rearrange equation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Specific heat capacity and thermal energy change equation
Sub_topics.description: Calculate thermal energy change with temperature change: ΔE = m c Δθ. Define specific heat capacity as energy required to raise temperature of 1 kg of substance by 1 °C. Units: ΔE in J, m in kg, c in J/kg °C, Δθ in °C. Apply equation to heating/cooling contexts.

Practical knowledge for determining specific heat capacity of materials by linking decrease of one energy store (or work done) to temperature rise and increase in thermal energy store; measure mass, temperature change, energy input; calculate c and evaluate uncertainties/errors.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Power as rate of energy transfer/work done
Sub_topics.description: Define power as rate of energy transfer or rate of doing work. Use equations: P = E/t and P = W/t. Units: P in watts (W), E in joules (J), W (work) in joules (J), t in seconds (s). Explain 1 W = 1 J/s and compare devices by power for same work/energy but different time.

Explain energy can be transferred usefully, stored or dissipated but not created/destroyed. Describe energy transfers in closed system leading to no net change in total energy. Explain that in all system changes some energy is dissipated into less useful stores (‘wasted’). Explain ways of reducing unwanted transfers (lubrication, thermal insulation). Relate rate of energy transfer by conduction to thermal conductivity; explain how building cooling rate depends on wall thickness and thermal conductivity (definition of thermal conductivity not required).

Calculate efficiency as: efficiency = useful output energy transfer / total input energy transfer, or efficiency = useful power output / total power input. Express efficiency as decimal or percentage. (HT) Describe ways to increase efficiency of intended energy transfer.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Energy resources: renewable vs non-renewable and impacts
Sub_topics.description: Recall main energy resources: fossil fuels (coal, oil, gas), nuclear fuel, bio-fuel, wind, hydroelectricity, geothermal, tides, Sun (solar), water waves. Define renewable as replenished as used. Compare uses of resources for transport, electricity generation and heating; explain reliability differences. Describe environmental impacts of different resources and explain patterns/trends in use. Recognise science can identify issues but solutions influenced by political/social/ethical/economic considerations; interpret related data using graphs/tables and percentages.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Standard circuit symbols and circuit diagrams
Sub_topics.description: Recognise and use standard circuit symbols; draw and interpret circuit diagrams accurately for common components (cell, battery, lamp, switch, resistor, variable resistor, diode, LED, thermistor, LDR, fuse, ammeter, voltmeter).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Charge, current and the Q=It equation
Sub_topics.description: Explain that for charge to flow in a closed circuit there must be a source of potential difference. Define current as rate of flow of charge. Use equation Q = I t (charge flow = current × time). Units: Q in coulombs (C), I in amperes (A), t in seconds (s). Know current has same value at any point in a single closed loop.

Explain that current through a component depends on potential difference across it and resistance; higher resistance gives smaller current for given p.d. Use equation V = I R. Units: V in volts (V), I in A, R in ohms (Ω). Use ‘potential difference’ (voltage acceptable) correctly.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: resistance factors (wire length; series/parallel resistors)
Sub_topics.description: Practical knowledge for setting up circuits from circuit diagrams to investigate factors affecting resistance: effect of length of wire at constant temperature; combinations of resistors in series and in parallel. Take measurements of V and I, calculate R, plot graphs (eg R vs length; V vs I) and evaluate accuracy/uncertainties.

Explain that for an ohmic conductor at constant temperature, current is directly proportional to potential difference so resistance is constant (linear I-V graph). Explain measuring component resistance using ammeter and voltmeter; draw appropriate circuit diagrams. Use I-V graphs to identify linear vs non-linear components.

Explain non-ohmic behaviour for filament lamps: resistance increases as temperature and current increase. Explain diode behaviour: current flows in one direction only with very high reverse resistance. Relate I-V curve shapes to component properties.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Thermistors and LDRs: resistance and applications
Sub_topics.description: Explain that thermistor resistance decreases as temperature increases; LDR resistance decreases as light intensity increases. Know applications: thermistors in thermostats; LDRs for automatic lighting when dark.

Practical knowledge for constructing circuits and measuring I–V characteristics for filament lamp, diode, and resistor at constant temperature; plot I–V graphs, interpret linear vs non-linear behaviour, and comment on component properties.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Series circuits: current, p.d. sharing and resistance
Sub_topics.description: Describe series circuit rules: same current through each component; supply p.d. shared between components; total resistance in series is sum: R_total = R1 + R2 (extend to more). Use these rules to construct/check series circuits, explain behaviour and calculate currents, p.d.s and resistances in dc series circuits using equivalent resistance; design/use dc series circuits for measurement/testing.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Parallel circuits: p.d., current splitting and resistance qualitative
Sub_topics.description: Describe parallel circuit rules: p.d. across each component same; total current equals sum of branch currents; total resistance of two resistors in parallel is less than smallest resistor. Explain qualitatively why adding resistors in series increases total resistance, while adding resistors in parallel decreases total resistance. (No requirement to calculate parallel equivalent resistance.)

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Direct vs alternating potential difference; UK mains values
Sub_topics.description: Explain difference between direct and alternating potential difference. Recall UK mains electricity is ac with frequency 50 Hz and about 230 V.

Describe three-core cable wiring: live (brown), neutral (blue), earth (green/yellow). Explain live carries alternating p.d.; neutral completes circuit; earth is safety wire preventing appliance case becoming live; neutral near earth potential (0 V); earth 0 V and carries current only in fault. Explain why live wire may be dangerous even when switch open; explain dangers of connecting live wire to earth.
Explain power transfer in circuit devices: P = V I and P = I^2 R. Units: P in W, V in V, I in A, R in Ω. Apply equations to calculate power and link to energy transfers over time.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Electrical energy transfer equations (E=Pt and E=QV)
Sub_topics.description: Explain that appliances transfer energy; energy transferred depends on time on and power rating. Use equations: E = P t and E = Q V. Units: E in J, P in W, t in s, Q in C, V in V. Describe examples of energy transfers from batteries/mains to kinetic energy (motors) or heating devices. Relate appliance power ratings to changes in stored energy during use.

Describe National Grid as system of cables and transformers linking power stations to consumers; electrical power transferred using grid. Explain step-up transformers increase p.d. for transmission and step-down decrease p.d. for domestic use; explain why this is efficient (reduced energy loss). (HT) Use transformer power equation on sheet: Vp Ip = Vs Is; select and apply to problems. Detailed transformer structure not required.

Define density using ρ = m/V. Units: density in kg/m^3, mass in kg, volume in m^3. Apply equation where mass is conserved. Use particle model to explain differences between solids, liquids, gases and differences in density in terms of particle arrangement; draw/interpret simple particle diagrams.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: density of solids and liquids
Sub_topics.description: Practical knowledge for measuring density of regular and irregular solids and liquids: measure mass; determine volume from dimensions for regular objects and by displacement for irregular objects; measure dimensions using ruler/micrometer/Vernier callipers. Record measurements with appropriate precision and calculate density; evaluate uncertainties.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Changes of state and conservation of mass
Sub_topics.description: Describe that mass is conserved when substances change state (melting, freezing, boiling, evaporating, condensing, sublimating). Distinguish physical changes of state from chemical changes because original properties recovered on reversal.

Define internal energy as total kinetic and potential energy of particles (atoms/molecules) in a system. Explain heating changes internal energy by increasing particle energy, which either raises temperature or causes change of state.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Specific heat capacity in particle model context
Sub_topics.description: Use ΔE = m c Δθ to calculate energy change when temperature changes; explain increase in temperature depends on mass, material and energy input. Distinguish specific heat capacity meaning and apply to contexts (overlaps with Energy topic but assessed here too).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Specific latent heat and change of state calculations
Sub_topics.description: Explain latent heat: energy needed for change of state; during change of state energy changes internal energy not temperature. Define specific latent heat as energy required to change state of 1 kg with no temperature change. Use equation E = m L; units: E in J, m in kg, L in J/kg. Distinguish latent heat of fusion vs vaporisation. Interpret heating/cooling graphs including plateaus for changes of state; distinguish specific heat capacity vs specific latent heat.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Gas pressure, temperature and particle motion
Sub_topics.description: Explain molecules of gas in constant random motion; temperature relates to average kinetic energy. Explain changing temperature of gas at constant volume changes pressure; relate pressure to particle collisions with container walls. Explain qualitative relationship between temperature and pressure at constant volume.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Structure of the atom and energy levels
Sub_topics.description: Recall atom radius about 1×10−10 m; nucleus is positive with protons and neutrons; electrons negative surrounding nucleus; nucleus radius <1/10 000 atom radius; most mass in nucleus. Describe electrons arranged at different energy levels; electron arrangement changes by absorption/emission of electromagnetic radiation (move to higher/lower energy levels). Use standard form where appropriate.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Atomic number, mass number, isotopes and ions
Sub_topics.description: Explain electrons = protons in neutral atom; atomic number = proton number; mass number = protons + neutrons. Represent atoms with nuclear notation. Define isotopes as same element with different neutrons. Explain atoms form positive ions by losing outer electrons. Relate isotope differences to representations, charges and masses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Development of the atomic model (physics context)
Sub_topics.description: As in chemistry: describe changes in atomic model due to new evidence: spheres → electron discovery → plum pudding → alpha scattering → nuclear model → Bohr energy levels → proton → neutron evidence by Chadwick. Explain why scattering changed model and differences between plum pudding and nuclear models; peer review and communication of findings; details of Bohr calculations/Chadwick method not required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Radioactive decay, activity and types of nuclear radiation
Sub_topics.description: Explain some nuclei unstable and emit radiation to become more stable; radioactive decay is random. Define activity as rate of decay measured in becquerel (Bq). Define count-rate as decays recorded per second by detector (eg Geiger-Muller). Describe nuclear radiation types: alpha (α) = 2 protons + 2 neutrons (helium nucleus); beta (β) = high-speed electron from nucleus as neutron turns into proton; gamma (γ) = electromagnetic radiation from nucleus; neutron (n). Required knowledge of α, β, γ limited to penetration, range in air, and ionising power. Apply to uses and evaluate best radiation source for a situation (risk/benefit).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nuclear equations for alpha and beta decay
Sub_topics.description: Use nuclear equations to represent decay; represent alpha as 4/2 He and beta as 0/−1 e. Explain alpha decay decreases mass and atomic numbers; beta decay leaves mass number unchanged but increases atomic number by 1; gamma emission changes neither mass nor charge. Write balanced nuclear equations for single α and β decay by balancing atomic and mass numbers; identifying daughter element not required. Use names/symbols of common nuclei/particles as provided.

Define half-life as time for number of nuclei/activity/count-rate to halve. Explain relationship to random nature of decay. Determine half-life from given data/graphs. (HT) Calculate net decline as ratio after a given number of half-lives.

Define radioactive contamination as unwanted radioactive material on/in object; hazard due to decay of contaminating atoms; radiation type affects hazard. Define irradiation as exposing object to radiation; irradiated object does not become radioactive. Compare hazards of contamination and irradiation; describe precautions to protect against radiation sources. Understand importance of publishing/sharing radiation effects studies for peer review.
Distinguish scalar quantities (magnitude only) from vector quantities (magnitude and direction). Represent vectors with arrows: length shows magnitude, direction shows vector direction.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Contact and non-contact forces; interaction pairs
Sub_topics.description: Define force as push or pull due to interaction with another object. Distinguish contact forces (friction, air resistance/drag, tension, normal contact) and non-contact forces (gravitational, electrostatic, magnetic). Know force is vector. Describe interaction between pairs of objects producing forces on each; represent forces as vectors.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Weight, mass and gravitational field strength
Sub_topics.description: Define weight as force due to gravity; gravity near Earth due to gravitational field. Weight depends on gravitational field strength. Use equation W = m g with units W in N, m in kg, g in N/kg (given). Explain weight acts at centre of mass. Know weight and mass directly proportional; weight measured with calibrated spring balance/newtonmeter; use proportionality symbol ∝ appropriately.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Resultant force and free-body diagrams (incl HT resolution)
Sub_topics.description: Define resultant force as single force having same effect as multiple forces combined. Calculate resultant of two forces in a straight line. (HT) Use free-body diagrams to describe forces on isolated object/system; describe balanced forces (resultant zero). (HT) Resolve single force into two perpendicular components; use vector diagrams (scale drawings) to determine resultant of two forces including magnitude and direction and illustrate equilibrium and resolution.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Work done by a force and energy transfer
Sub_topics.description: Explain work done when force causes displacement; use equation W = F s (distance moved along line of action). Units: W in J, F in N, s in m. Know 1 J = 1 N m. Describe energy transfer when work is done; convert between newton-metres and joules. Explain work done against friction increases temperature of object.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Elastic and inelastic deformation; Hooke’s law
Sub_topics.description: Give examples of forces in stretching/bending/compressing; explain why more than one force needed to change shape of stationary object. Distinguish elastic vs inelastic deformation. State extension of elastic spring is directly proportional to force provided limit of proportionality not exceeded. Use F = k e (also applies to compression). Identify linear vs non-linear force-extension relationships; calculate spring constant in linear cases; interpret data from force-extension investigations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Elastic potential energy and work done in stretching
Sub_topics.description: Explain that stretching spring stores elastic potential energy equal to work done (if not inelastically deformed). Calculate work done and energy stored using Ee = 1/2 k e^2 (up to limit of proportionality). Calculate related stored energies and transfers.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: force and extension for a spring
Sub_topics.description: Practical knowledge for investigating relationship between force and extension for a spring: measure extension for varying forces; plot force-extension graph; determine spring constant; identify limit of proportionality; evaluate uncertainties and method improvements.

Define distance as how far object moves (scalar, no direction). Define displacement as distance moved in straight line from start to finish with direction (vector). Express displacement with magnitude and direction; apply unit conversions and proportional reasoning in mechanics contexts.

Define speed as scalar; recognise speed usually varies. Recall typical speeds: walking ~1.5 m/s, running ~3 m/s, cycling ~6 m/s; recall typical speeds for transport; speed of sound in air ~330 m/s. Measure distance and time to calculate speed. Use equation s = v t for constant speed; calculate average speed for non-uniform motion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Velocity as vector (HT circular motion idea)
Sub_topics.description: Define velocity as speed in a given direction (vector). Explain vector-scalar distinction for displacement/distance and velocity/speed. (HT) Explain qualitatively that circular motion can have constant speed but changing velocity (direction changes).

Draw distance–time graphs; interpret gradients as speed; translate between graphical and numerical forms; determine speed from graph. (HT) For accelerating object, determine speed at a particular time by drawing tangent and measuring gradient at that time.

Calculate average acceleration using a = Δv/t; units m/s^2. Recognise deceleration as negative acceleration and estimate magnitudes of everyday accelerations. Determine acceleration from gradient of velocity–time graph. (HT) Calculate distance/displacement from area under velocity–time graph; measure area by counting squares when appropriate. Use equation for uniform acceleration: v^2 − u^2 = 2 a s (given). Recall free-fall acceleration near Earth ~9.8 m/s^2. Explain terminal velocity: object falling through fluid accelerates then reaches zero resultant force and constant terminal velocity.

Apply Newton’s First Law: if resultant force is zero, stationary object stays stationary; moving object continues at same velocity. Apply to steady-speed vehicle (driving force balances resistive forces). Explain that velocity changes only when resultant force acts. (HT) Define inertia as tendency to continue in state of rest or uniform motion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Newton’s Second Law (F=ma) and inertial mass (HT)
Sub_topics.description: Use Newton’s Second Law: acceleration proportional to resultant force and inversely proportional to mass; equation F = m a. Estimate speeds/accelerations/forces for road transport. Use approximate symbol ~. (HT) Explain inertial mass as measure of difficulty changing velocity; inertial mass defined as ratio F/a.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: force, mass and acceleration
Sub_topics.description: Practical knowledge for investigating effect of varying force on acceleration for constant mass, and effect of varying mass on acceleration for constant force; measure motion (speed/acceleration) using suitable apparatus; plot relationships; interpret proportionalities and evaluate uncertainties/systematic/random errors.

Apply Newton’s Third Law: when two objects interact, forces they exert on each other are equal and opposite. Apply to equilibrium and interaction examples; recognise paired forces act on different objects.

Define stopping distance as thinking distance (during reaction time) + braking distance (while braking force acts). Explain that for a given braking force, greater speed gives greater stopping distance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reaction time: typical values and influencing factors
Sub_topics.description: Know typical reaction times 0.2–0.9 s and that they vary. Explain factors affecting reaction time: tiredness, drugs, alcohol, distractions. Explain methods used to measure reaction time and interpret/evaluate measurements; evaluate effect of factors on thinking distance using data.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Factors affecting braking distance (road and vehicle conditions)
Sub_topics.description: Explain braking distance affected by adverse road/weather conditions (wet/icy) and vehicle condition (brakes/tyres). Explain safety implications and estimate variation of stopping distance with speed using typical data and proportional reasoning.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Braking forces, energy and dangers of large deceleration
Sub_topics.description: Explain that braking involves friction doing work reducing vehicle kinetic energy and increasing brake temperature. Explain greater speed requires greater braking force to stop in certain distance; greater braking force gives greater deceleration; large decelerations risk overheating and loss of control; explain dangers. (HT) Estimate forces involved in typical road deceleration scenarios.
(HT) Define momentum p as property of moving objects: p = m v. Units: kg m/s. Apply equation in calculations.

(HT) Explain conservation of momentum in closed system: total momentum before event equals total momentum after. Use momentum as a model to describe/explain collisions and other events; apply to calculations and qualitative explanations.

Describe waves as transverse or longitudinal. Identify ripples on water surface as transverse. Describe longitudinal waves as compressions and rarefactions; sound waves in air are longitudinal. Describe difference between wave types. Explain evidence that in water ripples and sound waves it is the wave/energy that travels, not the medium (water/air) itself.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Wave properties: amplitude, wavelength, frequency, period
Sub_topics.description: Define amplitude as maximum displacement from undisturbed position; wavelength as distance between equivalent points on adjacent waves; frequency as number of waves passing a point each second. Use relationship T = 1/f for period (T in s, f in Hz). Identify amplitude and wavelength on diagrams.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Wave speed equation and measuring wave speeds
Sub_topics.description: Use wave equation v = f λ (v in m/s, f in Hz, λ in m). Describe methods to measure speed of sound in air and speed of ripples on water surface, including choosing suitable apparatus, taking measurements, recording data and evaluating methods.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: measuring frequency, wavelength and speed of waves
Sub_topics.description: Practical knowledge for making observations to identify suitable apparatus to measure frequency, wavelength and speed of waves in ripple tank and waves in a solid; take measurements and calculate v using v=fλ; justify apparatus choices and evaluate uncertainties.

Describe electromagnetic (EM) waves as transverse waves transferring energy from source to absorber. Know EM spectrum is continuous; all EM waves travel at same velocity in a vacuum/air. Order from long wavelength/low frequency to short/high frequency: radio, microwave, infrared, visible (red to violet), ultraviolet, X-rays, gamma rays. Know eyes detect only visible light. Give examples illustrating energy transfer by EM waves.

(HT) Explain that substances may absorb/transmit/refract/reflect EM waves differently depending on wavelength; refraction due to speed change in different media. Construct ray diagrams for refraction at boundary; use wavefront diagrams to explain refraction due to speed change.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: IR absorption/radiation and surface nature
Sub_topics.description: Practical knowledge for investigating how amount of infrared radiation absorbed or radiated by a surface depends on surface nature (eg colour/finish). Measure temperature changes, control variables, record and interpret data, evaluate uncertainties.

(HT) Describe that radio waves can be produced by oscillations in electrical circuits; when absorbed they may induce alternating current with same frequency. Explain that changes in atoms and nuclei can generate and absorb EM waves across a wide range; gamma rays originate from nuclear changes.

Describe hazards of ultraviolet, X-rays and gamma rays as ionising radiation; effects depend on type and dose. UV causes skin ageing and increased skin cancer risk; X-rays and gamma rays cause gene mutations and cancer. Draw conclusions from data about risks and consequences of exposure.

Know practical applications: radio (TV/radio), microwaves (satellite communications, cooking), infrared (heaters, cooking, IR cameras), visible light (fibre optics), ultraviolet (energy-efficient lamps, sun tanning), X-rays/gamma rays (medical imaging and treatments). (HT) Explain briefly why each wave type is suitable for its application (penetration, absorption, frequency, wavelength).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Magnetic poles; permanent vs induced magnetism
Sub_topics.description: Know magnetic poles are where forces strongest. Describe forces between magnets: like poles repel, unlike attract; non-contact force. Define permanent magnet produces its own magnetic field. Define induced magnet as material that becomes magnet in a magnetic field; induced magnetism always causes attraction; induced magnet loses magnetism quickly when removed. Describe difference between permanent and induced magnets.

Define magnetic field as region around magnet where force acts on another magnet or magnetic material (iron, steel, cobalt, nickel). Force between magnet and magnetic material always attraction. Field strength depends on distance; strongest at poles. Define direction of field at a point as direction of force on a north pole; field lines from north to south pole. Describe how to plot field pattern using compass; draw bar magnet field pattern showing strength/direction changes. Explain compass behaviour and Earth’s magnetic field; relate to evidence that Earth’s core must be magnetic.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Magnetic fields due to currents; solenoids and electromagnets
Sub_topics.description: Describe that a current in a conducting wire produces magnetic field around wire; field strength depends on current and distance. Explain solenoid increases field strength; field inside solenoid strong and uniform; field pattern similar to bar magnet. Explain iron core increases field strength; define electromagnet as solenoid with iron core. Describe demonstrations of magnetic effect of current; draw field patterns for straight wire and solenoid with field direction; explain solenoid arrangement increases effect.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Motor effect and Fleming’s left-hand rule (HT)
Sub_topics.description: (HT) Describe motor effect: conductor carrying current in magnetic field experiences force; magnet and conductor exert equal and opposite forces. Use Fleming’s left-hand rule to relate directions of force, current and magnetic field. Recall factors affecting force size. Use equation for conductor at right angles: F = B I l (F in N, B in tesla T, I in A, l in m) and apply to calculations.
(HT) Explain that coil carrying current in magnetic field tends to rotate; this is basis of electric motor. Explain how forces on sides of coil cause rotation.
